title: 104_hr2463
content: The Act may be cited as the "Radiation Experimentation Compensation Act of 1995". It includes findings, purpose, and an apology. The Congress finds that since the 1940's, the Federal Government conducted secret radiation experiments in the United States without informed consent for research purposes, not for medical benefits. The Federal Government failed to inform individuals tested about the harmful effects of radiation experiments, causing harm and health problems. Congress presumes that these experiments led to excess cancers and diseases, putting innocent individuals at risk unknowingly. The Government should take responsibility for the lives and health of those involved. The Federal Government failed to inform individuals tested about harmful radiation experiments, leading to health problems. Congress apologizes and aims to provide partial restitution for the burdens borne by the affected individuals and their families. The Trust Fund established in Section 3 aims to provide partial restitution for individuals affected by harmful radiation experiments. The "Radiation Experimentation Compensation Trust Fund" is established in the Treasury of the United States and administered by the Secretary of the Treasury. Amounts in the Fund will be invested and any interest or proceeds will be credited to the Fund. The Fund will be available for disbursement by the Attorney General under section 5 and will terminate when the authorized amount is appropriated. The "Radiation Experimentation Compensation Trust Fund" is established in the Treasury of the United States and administered by the Secretary of the Treasury. Amounts in the Fund will be invested and any interest or proceeds will be credited to the Fund. The Fund will be available for disbursement by the Attorney General under section 5 and will terminate when the authorized amount is appropriated. There are authorized to be appropriated to the Fund $2,500,000, which will remain available until expended. If all amounts in the Fund have not been expended after 22 years, investments will be liquidated, receipts deposited back into the Fund, and remaining funds transferred to the Treasury's miscellaneous receipts account. SEC. 4. CLAIMS ELIGIBLE FOR PAYMENT. Any individual subjected to non-consensual injection of plutonium or zirconium, or total body radiation by the Federal Government between 1940 and 1974 is eligible for a $50,000 payment upon filing a claim meeting the Act's requirements. The term "experiment" refers to research tests on radiation effects on humans conducted by the Federal Government. The term "Federal Government" includes the legislative, judicial, or executive branches of the United States government, any agency or entity funded or approved by them for experiments involving plutonium, zirconium, or total body radiation. The term "informed consent" refers to consent given by an individual or their guardian for participation in an experiment after full disclosure of the experiment's nature and potential consequences. Exercise judgment to determine if the individual should participate in the experiment. SEC. 5. DETERMINATION AND PAYMENT OF CLAIMS. The Attorney General will establish filing procedures for individuals to submit claims for payments under the Act. Each claim will be reviewed to determine if it meets the requirements, and payments will be made from the Fund for eligible claims. Payments may be offset by amounts received from other awards or settlements. "Payments under this Act can be made based on a final award or settlement for participation in an experiment, including those under the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act. Such payments may offset awards received from other sources. Subrogation rights apply upon payment of a claim." Upon payment under this Act, the Federal Government has subrogation rights to any claims the individual may have against others due to their participation in an experiment. If the individual is deceased, the payment will be made to their surviving spouse. If the individual is not survived by a spouse, the payment will be made to their children, then to their parents, and finally to their grandchildren in equal shares. If an individual eligible for payment under this Act dies before filing a claim, the payment will be made to their siblings, then to their grandparents in equal shares. If an individual eligible for payment under this Act dies before filing a claim, a survivor can file a claim on their behalf. Definitions include children, grandchildren, and grandparents of the individual. The term "parent" includes fathers and mothers through adoption, "sibling of the individual" means a child of the parent or parents, and "spouse" refers to a person married to the individual for at least 12 months before their death. Within 18 months of filing a claim under this Act, the Attorney General will determine eligibility and make payments if requirements are met. (e) Settlement in Full of Claims Against United States.--Payment under this Act, when accepted by an individual or their survivors, shall fully satisfy all claims against the United States arising from the experiment. No administrative costs incurred by the Attorney General can be deducted from the payment. The Attorney General's duties under this section end when the Fund terminates. Payments under this Act are treated according to internal revenue laws. The Attorney General shall use existing resources to carry out functions under this Act and may issue necessary regulations. Initial regulations must be issued within 120 days of enactment. An individual's claim for compensation can be subject to judicial review. Judicial review of denied compensation claims under the Act can be sought in a US district court. The court will review the denial based on the administrative record and can overturn it if found to be arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, or not in accordance with the law. Appeals can be made to higher Federal courts. SEC. 6. CLAIMS NOT ASSIGNABLE OR TRANSFERABLE. No claim under this Act can be assigned or transferred. SEC. 7. LIMITATION ON CLAIMS. Individuals must file a claim within 20 years of the Act's enactment to receive payment. SEC. 8. ATTORNEY OR AGENT FEES. Representatives cannot receive more than 10% of the payment for services related to a claim. SEC. 9. CERTAIN CLAIMS NOT AFFECTED BY PAYMENT. SEC. 9. A payment under section 5(c)(1) does not count as compensation or reimbursement for imposing liability on the individual to repay insurance or worker's compensation. It also does not impact any claims against insurance carriers or persons regarding insurance or worker's compensation. SEC. 10. No contracts or payments can be made under this Act in any fiscal year without prior appropriations.
